notes: Five of Central's Members are also Members of New Horizon Electric Cooperative (NHEC). NHEC maintains a portion of Central's transmission lines. Central paid NHEC $1,590,760 and $2,138,796 in 2017 and 2016, respectively. In 2017, NHEC paid Central $48,000 for management services.

address: 1331 Sunday Dr, Raleigh, NC 27607, USA
notes: In 2017 Central became a member of the Alliance for Cooperatives Energy Services Power Marketing, LLC (ACES). ACES is a nationwide energy management company. At the end of five years, Central can exit the organization and receive a refund equal to its pro rata share of ACES equity. Central is committed to purchase a minimum level of services from ACES starting at $195,000 annually and increasing 2% annually for a period of five years. Any services above these minimums will be paid at ACES actual cost. Central paid ACES $245,715 in 2017.

address: 101 Enterprise Pkwy, West Columbia, SC 29170, USA
notes: Central is a member of the Cooperative Electric Energy Utility Supply, Inc. (CEE-US).CEE-US is organized to provide member cooperatives with the ability to purchase utility construction and repair materials and supplies on a combined basis. Central purchased $3,612,141 and $2,505,960 in CEE-US' fiscal years ending September 30, 2017 and 2016, respectively. Central's patronage capital in CEE-US represents approximately 2.5% of total CEE-US patronage capital.

address: 808 Knox Abbott Dr, West Columbia, SC 29033, USA
notes: Central and its Members created KW Savings Co. (KWS) to facilitate on-billing financing of energy efficiency home improvements for Members. Central received a $740,000 Rural Economic Development Loan & Grant (REDLG) loan from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), which was loaned to KWS for low interest loans on energy efficiency projects for distribution member households. KWS returns this money to Central at approximately the same time the loans are repaid by the distribution members. As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, $339,167 and $431,667 was outstanding, respectively. In 2017 and 2016, Central provided KWS with $29,877 and $3,823, respectively, to cover program administrative costs. In 2017, KWS paid Central $5,000 for accounting services.

notes:
The Office of Regulatory Staff (ORS) represents the public interest of South Carolina in utility regulation for the major utility industries -- electric, natural gas, telecommunications, transportation, and water/wastewater -- before the Public Service Commission of South Carolina, the court system, the South Carolina General Assembly, and federal regulatory bodies. The ORS also has responsibility for oversight of railroad safety and natural gas pipeline safety in South Carolina.

The public interest, as defined by the South Carolina General Assembly, is as follows:

The concerns of the using and consuming public with respect to public utility services, regardless of the class of customer, and preservation of continued investment in and maintenance of utility facilities so as to provide reliable and high-quality utility services.

address: 808 Knox Abbott Dr, Cayce, SC 29033, USA
notes: EnlightenSC is an energy education program developed by educators for the consumer-owned electric cooperatives in South Carolina. The co-ops created EnlightenSC as a way to help teachers better access energy-related information and activities for their classrooms, resources designed to get young people excited about science, technology, engineering and mathematics: the STEM subjects. This website is a clearinghouse of lessons and activities, compiled from resources across the country, and correlated to S.C. science education standards for each grade level. The program has expanded to include a summer graduate courses for educators at no charge. EnlightenSC also sponsors the SC 4H Engineering Challenge – a competition for S.C. students.

address: Richmond Hwy, Virginia, USA
notes: Youth Development The Electric Cooperative Youth Tour has brought high school students to Washington, D.C. for a week in June every year since the late 1950s. Students apply and are selected for this program by their local electric cooperative. We believe that students should see their nation’s capital up close, learn about the political process and interact with their elected official

notes: Disabled Veteran Eduation Program The CoBank/No Barriers program for rural veterans provides an opportunity for veterans with disabilities to challenge their own limitations, both real and perceived, physical and mental. Through successfully completing demanding activities like rafting, rock climbing and hiking, participants become better-equipped to overcome the obstacles they face in their daily lives. By sharing the experience with other veterans with disabilities, they also build a network of support that can last a lifetime.

notes:
Green Power is electricity generated by renewable resources like decomposing garbage in selected landfills, solar and wind. These resources are replenished naturally and  minimize harm to the environment.

 

Santee Cooper launched the Green Power Program in response to increased customer interest in renewable energy and concern for the environment. By taking this initial step to meet and encourage the growing demand for renewable energy, we can help reduce the reliance on limited resources while improving and preserving the environment for future generations.

address: 808 Knox Abbott Dr, West Columbia, SC 29033, USA
notes: One of the most successful community service efforts in which we’re involved has been the Operation Round Up program. Founded by Palmetto Electric in 1989, Operation Round Up has been an incredibly successful way in which we have been able to help the less fortunate in our community. Through Operation Round Up, Palmetto Electric automatically rounds up a participating member’s electric bills to the next highest dollar. For example, a consumer’s monthly bill of $52.73 would be automatically rounded up to $53.00, with the additional 27 cents going to the Operation Round Up fund. On an annual basis, we are able to donate roughly six dollars for each participating customer – and that pool of money is then allocated to a variety of worthy causes throughout our service area.
